<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 121, 648, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 184, 189]]<|/det|>
PHYSICS Paper 1 Multiple Choice

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[847, 172, 908, 187]]<|/det|>
9702/11

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[758, 195, 908, 211]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025 1 hour 15 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 248, 507, 266]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 279, 438, 296]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 306, 540, 323]]<|/det|>
Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 231, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 351, 603, 379]]<|/det|>
- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. - For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Choose the one you consider correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 382, 682, 399]]<|/det|>
and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet. - Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 413, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
- Write in soft pencil. - Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 443, 521, 460]]<|/det|>
spaces provided unless this has been done for you. - Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 474, 366, 491]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes. - You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 536, 222, 547]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 550, 391, 567]]<|/det|>
- The total mark for this paper is 40. - Each correct answer will score one mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 579, 570, 596]]<|/det|>
- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 127, 89]]<|/det|>
Data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 102, 272, 116]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g=9.81 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 135, 306, 150]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c=3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 168, 239, 181]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e=1.60 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 200, 250, 214]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \mathrm{u}=1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 232, 250, 247]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}}=1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 265, 256, 280]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}}=9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 297, 239, 311]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}}=6.02 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 330, 239, 344]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R=8.31 \mathrm{~JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 361, 250, 376]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k=1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~JK}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 393, 261, 407]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 425, 286, 440]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\varepsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~Fm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[461, 446, 532, 477]]<|/det|>
\[
\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\right)=8.99 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~mF}^{-1}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 495, 217, 508]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h=6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 526, 314, 543]]<|/det|>
Stefan-Boltzmann constant \(\sigma=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2} \mathrm{~K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 587, 168, 600]]<|/det|>
Formulae

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 614, 322, 629]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 636, 565, 651]]<|/det|>
\[
v^{2}=u^{2}+2 a s
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 665, 250, 680]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p=\rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 696, 154, 711]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F=\rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 726, 339, 743]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_{0}=\frac{f_{s} v}{v \pm v_{s}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 767, 209, 780]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I=A n v q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 797, 228, 812]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R=R_{1}+R_{2}+ \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 823, 239, 840]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R}=\frac{1}{R_{1}}+\frac{1}{R_{2}}+\ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 341, 91]]<|/det|> 1 Which quantity is a vector? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 228, 118]]<|/det|> A pressure <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 256, 143]]<|/det|> B temperature <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 154, 211, 170]]<|/det|> C weight <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 195, 193]]<|/det|> D work <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 920, 241]]<|/det|> 2 Four students, \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\), have completed an experiment to determine the acceleration of free fall, \(g\). Each student repeated the experiment three times. The determined values of \(g\) are <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 274, 269]]<|/det|> shown in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 626, 302]]<|/det|> Which set of results has a high precision and a low accuracy? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 603, 466]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall/ \(\mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\)
experiment 1
experiment 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 318, 504, 334]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[184, 344, 295, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 369, 153, 385]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 395, 153, 410]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 421, 153, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 446, 153, 461]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 493, 567, 510]]<|/det|> 3 The diameter of a ball is measured as \((5.26 \pm 0.02) \mathrm{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 525, 594, 542]]<|/det|> What is the absolute uncertainty in the volume of the ball? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 550, 228, 567]]<|/det|> A \(0.29 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 550, 394, 567]]<|/det|> B \(0.87 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 550, 551, 567]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 1.1 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 550, 717, 567]]<|/det|> D \(7.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 396, 89]]<|/det|>
4 Two vectors, \(X\) and \(Y\), are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 103, 461, 159]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 110, 411, 128]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 173, 477, 187]]<|/det|>
What are the directions of \(X+Y\) and \(X-Y\) ?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 201, 484, 587]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 614, 918, 631]]<|/det|>
5 A ball is projected vertically downwards with an initial velocity of \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\). Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 764, 676]]<|/det|>
What is the displacement from its initial position of the ball after a time of 1.5 s ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 195, 703]]<|/det|>
A 11 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 688, 361, 703]]<|/det|>
B 19 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 688, 528, 703]]<|/det|>
C 37 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 688, 695, 703]]<|/det|>
D 41 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 734, 830, 750]]<|/det|>
6 A surveyor's device emits a pulse of light. The light is reflected from a wall 150 m away.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 764, 918, 780]]<|/det|>
What is the total time taken for the pulse to travel from the device to the wall and then back to the device?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 808, 214, 823]]<|/det|>
A 0.05 ns

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 808, 380, 823]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.10 \mathrm{~ns}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 808, 548, 824]]<|/det|>
C \(0.50 \mu \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 808, 703, 824]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 1.0 \mu \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 7 Which equation of uniformly accelerated motion can be derived using only the gradient of a velocity-time graph? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 256, 138]]<|/det|> A \(s=\frac{1}{2}(u+v) t\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 146, 258, 165]]<|/det|> B \(s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 175, 234, 189]]<|/det|> C \(v=u+a t\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 199, 267, 216]]<|/det|> D \(v^{2}=u^{2}+2 a s\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 246, 918, 263]]<|/det|> 8 An object is projected horizontally from a table at time \(t=0\). The object falls in a uniform gravitational field. Air resistance is negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 290, 510, 307]]<|/det|> Graphs \(\mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q}, \mathrm{R}\) and S are velocity-time graphs. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[113, 320, 279, 423]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[189, 433, 210, 448]]<|/det|> P <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 320, 479, 423]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 433, 413, 448]]<|/det|> Q <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 320, 682, 423]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[596, 433, 616, 448]]<|/det|> R <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[722, 320, 885, 423]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[801, 433, 815, 448]]<|/det|> S <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 466, 869, 481]]<|/det|> Which graphs represent the horizontal and vertical components of the velocity of the object? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 493, 408, 621]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
10 A firework travels vertically upwards in air. Gases are pushed vertically downwards from the firework.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 616, 136]]<|/det|>
Several forces that act on the firework and gases are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 148, 513, 370]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 228, 689, 243]]<|/det|>
NOT TO SCALE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 477, 399]]<|/det|>
Which forces are a Newton's third law pair?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 427, 427]]<|/det|>
A air resistance and force on gases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 437, 355, 452]]<|/det|>
B air resistance and thrust

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 366, 479]]<|/det|>
C force on gases and thrust

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 488, 300, 505]]<|/det|>
D thrust and weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 533, 802, 549]]<|/det|>
11 Two blocks K and L slide towards each other along a horizontal frictionless surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 564, 747, 581]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the momentum of the two blocks just before they collide.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 597, 664, 681]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 695, 788, 711]]<|/det|>
During the collision, the blocks are in contact with each other for a time of 0.084 s .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 724, 918, 741]]<|/det|>
After the collision, the blocks separate and block \(L\) moves back along its original path with a momentum of \(0.12 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 769, 889, 785]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the average force exerted on block L by block K during the collision?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 796, 198, 811]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 3.1 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 796, 366, 811]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 4.0 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 796, 532, 811]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 6.9 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 798, 698, 811]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 7.1 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 12 Leonardo da Vinci proposed a flying machine that would work like a screw to lift the pilot into the air. The 'screw' is rotated by the pilot. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[372, 118, 626, 264]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 277, 638, 294]]<|/det|> The machine and the pilot together have a total mass of 120 kg . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 918, 323]]<|/det|> Which useful output power must the pilot provide to move vertically upwards at a constant speed of \(2.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) ? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 349, 198, 364]]<|/det|> A 48 W <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 349, 374, 364]]<|/det|> B 300 W <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 349, 540, 364]]<|/det|> C 470 W <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 349, 716, 364]]<|/det|> D 2900 W <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 394, 590, 411]]<|/det|> 13 Which row describes a pair of forces that forms a couple? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 423, 457, 567]]<|/det|>
direction of
the forces
magnitude of
the forces
A
opposite
different
B
opposite
equal
C
same
different
D
same
equal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 697, 91]]<|/det|>
14 A uniform cylinder of weight 25.0 N is suspended from a newton meter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 537, 120]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is fully submerged in water, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 472, 150]]<|/det|>
The reading on the newton meter is 10.0 N .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[350, 162, 648, 397]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 918, 426]]<|/det|>
The water is replaced by a liquid with a density \(10 \%\) greater than the density of water. The cylinder remains fully submerged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 501, 471]]<|/det|>
What is the new reading on the newton meter?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 198, 497]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 8.5 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 484, 363, 497]]<|/det|>
B 9.0 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 484, 543, 497]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 11.0 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 484, 708, 497]]<|/det|>
D 11.5 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 529, 918, 545]]<|/det|>
15 A student balances a 30 cm ruler on a fulcrum set at the 15 cm mark. She then places a 50 g mass on the 23 cm mark and a 20 g mass on the 11 cm mark, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 574, 782, 649]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 703, 676]]<|/det|>
Which mass should she place on the 7 cm mark to restore the balance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 190, 706]]<|/det|>
A 30 g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 688, 355, 706]]<|/det|>
B 40 g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 688, 524, 706]]<|/det|>
C 47 g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 688, 700, 706]]<|/det|>
D 133 g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 734, 645, 750]]<|/det|>
16 A submarine is at a depth of 130 m below the surface of the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 590, 782]]<|/det|>
The pressure on the submarine due to the sea water is \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 794, 606, 810]]<|/det|>
The submarine sinks to a depth of 260 m below the surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 825, 521, 840]]<|/det|>
Assume that the density of sea water is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 854, 918, 870]]<|/det|>
What is the difference between the pressures on the submarine due to the sea water at the two depths?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 898, 169, 912]]<|/det|>
A 0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 898, 361, 912]]<|/det|>
B \(0.5 p\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 898, 503, 913]]<|/det|>
C \(p\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 898, 678, 914]]<|/det|>
D \(2 p\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 521, 91]]<|/det|>
17 An object is falling in a uniform gravitational field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 866, 120]]<|/det|>
Which two quantities are sufficient to calculate the change in gravitational potential energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 428, 148]]<|/det|>
A mass and acceleration of free fall

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 158, 501, 175]]<|/det|>
B mass and change in vertical displacement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 438, 200]]<|/det|>
C weight and acceleration of free fall

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 209, 510, 225]]<|/det|>
D weight and change in vertical displacement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 254, 587, 270]]<|/det|>
18 The points \(X, Y\) and \(Z\) are on a rough, horizontal surface.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[366, 285, 634, 413]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 429, 703, 446]]<|/det|>
A box \(P\) is pushed across the surface from \(X\) to \(Y\) and then from \(Y\) to \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
The distance from \(X\) to \(Y\) is 3.0 m . The work done against the frictional force in moving the box from \(X\) to \(Y\) is 150 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 778, 521]]<|/det|>
The work done against the frictional force in moving the box from Y to Z is 200 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 590, 551]]<|/det|>
An identical box \(Q\) is pushed in a straight line from \(X\) to \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 564, 808, 581]]<|/det|>
The magnitude of the frictional force between the boxes and the surface is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 593, 753, 611]]<|/det|>
How much extra work is done against the frictional force in moving \(P\) than \(Q\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 201, 637]]<|/det|>
A 100 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 622, 366, 637]]<|/det|>
B 250 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 622, 532, 637]]<|/det|>
C 350 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 622, 700, 637]]<|/det|>
D 600 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 667, 603, 684]]<|/det|>
19 The momentum of a car of mass \(m\) increases from \(p_{1}\) to \(p_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 697, 550, 714]]<|/det|>
What is the increase in the kinetic energy of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 722, 245, 755]]<|/det|>
A \(\frac{\left(p_{2}{ }^{2}-p_{1}{ }^{2}\right)}{2 m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 722, 405, 755]]<|/det|>
B \(\frac{\left(p_{2}-p_{1}\right)^{2}}{2 m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 724, 551, 755]]<|/det|>
C \(\frac{p_{2}-p_{1}}{2 m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 724, 717, 755]]<|/det|>
D \(\frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{2 m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 550, 91]]<|/det|>
20 A parachutist is falling at constant (terminal) velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 382, 118]]<|/det|>
Which statement is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 736, 149]]<|/det|>
A Gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 157, 808, 175]]<|/det|>
B Gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of the parachutist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 747, 200]]<|/det|>
C Gravitational potential energy is converted into thermal energy of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 209, 816, 225]]<|/det|>
D Gravitational potential energy is converted into thermal energy of the parachutist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 918, 270]]<|/det|>
21 A student investigates a spring. The variation of the length of the spring with the force applied to the spring is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 297, 698, 436]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 460, 469]]<|/det|>
What is the spring constant of the spring?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 239, 495]]<|/det|>
A \(0.17 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 478, 405, 495]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.25 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 478, 562, 495]]<|/det|>
C \(4.0 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 478, 730, 495]]<|/det|>
D \(6.0 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 525, 669, 542]]<|/det|>
22 The graph shows the variation with force of the extension of a wire.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[265, 554, 734, 709]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 726, 898, 743]]<|/det|>
The force is gradually increased to a maximum at \(Q\) and then gradually decreased to zero at \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 755, 350, 770]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 782, 539, 799]]<|/det|>
A Along the line PQ , the wire obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 806, 653, 836]]<|/det|>
B Along the line RP , the spring constant is equal to \(\frac{\text { extension }}{\text { force }}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 839, 512, 856]]<|/det|>
C The wire has elastic deformation at point \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 866, 827, 883]]<|/det|>
D The work done in stretching the wire to P is equal to (force \(\times\) extension) at point P .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 693, 91]]<|/det|> 23 A uniform metal wire of length \(L\) and diameter \(d\) has spring constant \(k\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 457, 120]]<|/det|> What is the Young modulus of the metal? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 195, 161]]<|/det|> A \(\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4 k L}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 128, 358, 161]]<|/det|> B \(\frac{\pi d^{2}}{k L}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 131, 526, 161]]<|/det|> C \(\frac{k L}{\pi d^{2}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 131, 693, 161]]<|/det|> D \(\frac{4 k L}{\pi d^{2}}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 193, 570, 209]]<|/det|> 24 An aircraft produces a sound at a frequency of 30.0 Hz . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 220, 432, 239]]<|/det|> The speed of sound in air is \(330 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 918, 269]]<|/det|> The aircraft is directly in front of the stationary observer and travels in a straight line towards or away from the observer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 716, 314]]<|/det|> The observer hears the sound from the aircraft at a frequency of 20.0 Hz . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 328, 504, 344]]<|/det|> What is the speed and direction of the aircraft? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 507, 486]]<|/det|>
speed \(/ \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)
direction
A
110
away from observer
B
110
towards observer
C
165
away from observer
D
165
towards observer
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 513, 918, 529]]<|/det|> 25 Which statement about longitudinal and transverse wave motion for a progressive wave is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 744, 573]]<|/det|> A All transverse and longitudinal waves require a medium for propagation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 581, 918, 598]]<|/det|> B All transverse waves travel at the same speed, but longitudinal waves can travel at different speeds. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 918, 638]]<|/det|> C In both transverse waves and longitudinal waves, a particle with zero displacement has a maximum speed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 663, 918, 679]]<|/det|> D In a longitudinal wave there is a net movement of particles in the direction of travel of the wave, but there is no net movement of particles in a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 724, 891, 740]]<|/det|> 26 The diagram shows a progressive transverse wave on a stretched string at one instant in time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 753, 417, 770]]<|/det|> One point on the string is labelled X . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 782, 559, 799]]<|/det|> Which point on the string is \(270^{\circ}\) out of phase with \(X\) ? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[328, 813, 671, 918]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 792, 91]]<|/det|>
27 Which wavelength of electromagnetic radiation in free space could be green light?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 256, 118]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 4.9 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 101, 421, 118]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 6.6 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 101, 588, 118]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 5.5 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 101, 755, 118]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 8.6 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 148, 582, 165]]<|/det|>
28 Which group contains only waves that can be polarised?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 175, 504, 192]]<|/det|>
A infrared waves, radio waves, sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 201, 521, 218]]<|/det|>
B visible light waves, microwaves, radio waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 532, 243]]<|/det|>
C visible light waves, radio waves, sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 532, 270]]<|/det|>
D microwaves, visible light waves, sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 302, 918, 333]]<|/det|>
29 One wave has an amplitude of \(2 A\). A second wave has an amplitude of \(\frac{A}{2}\). The waves are otherwise identical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 579, 382]]<|/det|>
The two waves travel in opposite directions and overlap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 595, 426]]<|/det|>
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text { maximum amplitude of combined wave }}{\text { minimum amplitude of combined wave }} ?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 439, 173, 469]]<|/det|>
A \(\frac{3}{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 439, 340, 469]]<|/det|>
B \(\frac{5}{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 439, 507, 469]]<|/det|>
C \(\frac{5}{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 445, 669, 461]]<|/det|>
D 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 500, 863, 518]]<|/det|>
30 Light of wavelength 680 nm is incident normally on a diffraction grating with 450 lines \(\mathrm{mm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 531, 918, 547]]<|/det|>
What is the angle of diffraction of the second-order maximum in the diffraction pattern that is produced?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 574, 190, 588]]<|/det|>
A \(1.8^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 574, 355, 588]]<|/det|>
B \(3.5^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 574, 518, 588]]<|/det|>
C \(18^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 574, 684, 588]]<|/det|>
D \(38^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 618, 587, 635]]<|/det|>
31 A hollow tube is closed at one end and open at the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 649, 858, 667]]<|/det|>
A stationary sound wave of the lowest possible frequency, 820 Hz , is produced in the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 677, 432, 696]]<|/det|>
The speed of sound in air is \(330 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 708, 372, 727]]<|/det|>
What is the length of the tube?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 206, 752]]<|/det|>
A 10 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 737, 372, 752]]<|/det|>
B 20 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 737, 537, 752]]<|/det|>
C 40 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 737, 714, 752]]<|/det|>
D 160 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 782, 545, 799]]<|/det|>
32 Which expression gives the definition of resistance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 810, 466, 826]]<|/det|>
A current divided by potential difference

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 836, 482, 852]]<|/det|>
B current multiplied by potential difference

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 861, 466, 877]]<|/det|>
C potential difference divided by current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 888, 396, 904]]<|/det|>
D resistivity multiplied by length

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 669, 91]]<|/det|>
33 The graph shows the \(I-V\) characteristic of an electrical component.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 102, 642, 272]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 322, 302]]<|/det|>
What is the component?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 283, 329]]<|/det|>
A a filament lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 338, 521, 354]]<|/det|>
B a metallic conductor at constant temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 234, 379]]<|/det|>
C a resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 344, 405]]<|/det|>
D a semiconductor diode

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 435, 642, 452]]<|/det|>
34 The diagram shows six identical resistors connected in a circuit.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 462, 653, 744]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 755, 603, 772]]<|/det|>
In which branch of the circuit is the most power dissipated?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 782, 184, 799]]<|/det|>
A PQ

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 782, 353, 797]]<|/det|>
B QR

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 782, 515, 797]]<|/det|>
C RS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 782, 681, 797]]<|/det|>
D SP

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 792, 91]]<|/det|>
35 The diagram shows a circuit containing a thermistor, a fixed resistor and a battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 626, 122]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the \(I-V\) characteristics of both components.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 154, 366, 266]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[392, 133, 850, 318]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 331, 667, 348]]<|/det|>
The battery has an e.m.f. of 12 V and negligible internal resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 446, 377]]<|/det|>
What is the current in the fixed resistor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 388, 225, 403]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0.36 \mathrm{~mA}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 388, 391, 403]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.40 \mathrm{~mA}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 388, 557, 403]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 0.48 \mathrm{~mA}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 388, 725, 403]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 0.80 \mathrm{~mA}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 435, 648, 451]]<|/det|>
36 Two resistors of resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) are connected in parallel.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[355, 461, 642, 544]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 543, 577]]<|/det|>
What is the combined resistance between X and Y ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 595, 228, 612]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad R_{1}+R_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 585, 399, 621]]<|/det|>
B \(\frac{R_{1} R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 585, 565, 621]]<|/det|>
C \(\frac{R_{1}+R_{2}}{R_{1} R_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 585, 687, 621]]<|/det|>
D \(\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
37 A cell is connected in series with an ammeter and a variable resistor. A voltmeter is used to measure the p.d. across the variable resistor. The resistance of the variable resistor is varied,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 463, 120]]<|/det|>
and the p.d. and the current are recorded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 786, 150]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the variation with current of the p.d. across the variable resistor.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 164, 750, 516]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 463, 547]]<|/det|>
What is the internal resistance of the cell?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 222, 576]]<|/det|>
A \(0.050 \Omega\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 560, 366, 576]]<|/det|>
B \(1.6 \Omega\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 562, 529, 577]]<|/det|>
C \(20 \Omega\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 562, 695, 576]]<|/det|>
D \(23 \Omega\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 607, 504, 622]]<|/det|>
38 Which list contains only fundamental particles?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 634, 504, 651]]<|/det|>
A antineutrinos, baryons, neutrons, electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 466, 676]]<|/det|>
B mesons, electrons, neutrinos, protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 446, 702]]<|/det|>
C positrons, quarks, hadrons, protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 712, 454, 727]]<|/det|>
D quarks, positrons, neutrinos, leptons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
39 Which statement explains why alpha-particles have discrete energies, but beta-particles have a continuous range of energies?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
A Beta-particles have a much smaller mass than alpha-particles which means beta-particles can be emitted with a larger range of velocities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 158, 918, 175]]<|/det|>
B Only alpha-particles experience repulsion from the nucleus which is dependent on the number of protons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 199, 918, 216]]<|/det|>
C Only beta-particles are emitted with another lepton and some energy is transferred to the other lepton.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 239, 918, 256]]<|/det|>
D Only the energy of alpha-particles is discrete because the composition of alpha-particles is always the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 298, 548, 315]]<|/det|>
40 A hadron consists of antiquarks that are all identical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 874, 346]]<|/det|>
What is a possible value, in terms of the elementary charge \(e\), for the charge on the hadron?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 357, 178, 372]]<|/det|>
A \(0 e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 357, 355, 372]]<|/det|>
B \(+1 e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 357, 524, 372]]<|/det|>
C \(+2 e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 357, 689, 372]]<|/det|>
D \(+3 e\)
